kxkumJ8yIORIqy9pCjoJOA.text: Cold outside? Well here is your perfectly delicious winter warmer. Pho is simply glorious.From the first moment I walked in, I liked this place. The decor is really clean, minimalist and spacious. There is a really cute bar area too to have close access to the booze while your slurp on. The servers are super friendly and helpful. I wasn't really clear on the various types of Pho soups and noodles, and they helped me make my decisions no problem.There are lots of options on the menu, from veg options to meat and seafood. Also, there are add on and extra options, so you can really customise your soup, which is awesome. I opted for the traditional Pho soup with prawns and vegetable stock broth. It was absolutely delish, especially with all the wonderful add on herbs and spices they brought along with my soup. They added so much delicious, spicy flavour to the meal.

dibaaFT86hQtu2e3gstkAg.text: Hooray for Pho in Soho! There are a few others in London as part of the same chain, but this place is soup-er. I know. That pun is so awful, but I just had to use it.My first time was with Lizzie G on Tuesday, I had the spicy chicken Pho - which was to die for - and we shared the summer spring rolls. Nom.It was weird to be offered a bib to eat with though. Especially as NOBODY ELSE in the whole place had been offered the same. Shrug. It was pretty useful, we worked it the best we could :)I went again on Friday, this time trying the lemongrass beef bun noodles, served with a fresh salad and vegetable spring roll. Also gorgeous. Fresh, tasty and only £11 with a beer on the side. Definitely my new favourite haunt. Walk in, get a great meal for a good price. WIN.

q-ubjjqUbEk4FV-uf6EqYw.text: Went at the prompting of a friend who loves Pho. I have to say, I was impressed! It was flavorful yet light. Great for a cold damp evening! I'll be back!!!

VMkmH0G0rG7hwx17t4OBHw.text: I've been a fan of the original St John Street location of Vietnamese street food restaurant Pho since it opened and I'm happy to report that the food at this newest of Pho's five restaurants is just as yummy  and that this particular one is a rather snazzy setting to boot (lots with spacious yet private seating, evocative lighting and attractive design-y elements). Faves on the menu include goi cuon tom (fresh summer rolls with prawns and fresh herbs) and goi xoai (spicy green mango salad served with pork, dried shrimp and peanuts), the classic pho tai (thinly sliced steak served in beef stock with rice noodles and fresh herbs) and bun cha gio new nuong (pork and lemongrass meatballs with vermicelli noodles and stir fried toppings, fresh herbs, veggie spring roll and peanuts) - alll filling and certainly tasty! Pleased!

BhIVRO0K5wabx9QpbbXwfA.text: I really enjoyed Pho restaurant. The vibe and atmosphere was great and the food was amazing. Great place!

OFM64fxzJt9uBYNZbOgQhg.text: i love pho. the pho here isn't great, but when i'm craving some soup, and i'm in the area, it certainly does the trick. i like the atmosphere of this particular branch, having also previously ate at the one behind oxford circus. this one in soho is more atmospheric, and made for a lovely date with my boyfriend. service was good and quick too. my boyfriend always goes for the bun noodles and seems really happy with what he gets. he is so easily pleased when it comes to food though!it definitely isn't the cheapest, but it is reasonable, so i would recommend if you are in the area and want some vietnamese food in a nice, cosy space.

DR6Yg07fXf9uijPwWiuFZg.text: I love Vietnamese food- particularly Pho- so I was determined to try some while I was in London. This place is one of a chain and seemed to get decent reviews so we popped as we were in Soho.The waitress was friendly and the restaurant was busy- it filled up while we were there- about six when we arrived.We tried both the chicken and the prawn summer rolls- both good although I preferred the prawn goi cuon. Both the dips were lovely.My friend had the prams and noodles and he loved it. I had the Beef Pho with fillet beef- I chose the spicy option. It was good but not amazing. I think I would recommend choosing the normal Pho and add the flavours yourself. We shared a large Lao beer- nice and crisp- and then we both had a Vietnamese coffee. It always tastes like there is some chocolate in the coffee. The meal only cost £40 including service and was a tasty. I would recommend dropping in and trying Pho if you are nearby.

XBWI4y-6txfDvb8oUGWgvQ.text: This place has many virtues.  First, they are very explicitlyveg-friendly (even labeling fish sauce and offering alternatives,which is virtually unheard of at East Asian places).  Second, thebuilding is lovely and the ambiance wonderful.Set against this, there are a few negatives.  First, the food wasn'tterribly flavorful: the pho came with fresh herbs that were actuallyfresh, so the broth had a lovely delicacy to it, but the rest was notdelicate so much as bland.  Second, there was little by way of actualvegetable, just lots of noodle.  Third, the server was extremelyfriendly and also extremely forgetful.For people who don't like meaty, beefy broths, the broth here was areal virtue.  That alone can put it well over threshold for some.  Ifthat's not enough of a draw, the rest makes it ho-hum (especially inLondon, which has so much else to offer).

9uFrVN_PW4T5cbevWvQLxQ.text: Amazing place! My favourite Asian place in Soho. Food here is fantastic. Great to finally have a good Vietnamese restaurant in Soho! The noodle soups are the best. I LOVE the spicy ones... Cool atmosphere and staff too.

QaIeE9G3HsdZ0FJBlyVveg.text: How Vietnamese food should not look like can be seen on my blog herehungryinlondon.com/2011/… I met my Vietnamese food loving friend Naomi one Sunday in Soho with the aim to finally try out Viet in Greek Street,which has been strongly recommended to me by Leluu (who is Vietnamese and therefore must know where to get the most authentic and delicious Vietnamese grub). To our unimaginable disappointment,Viet was closed. We were not ready to give up yet on our quest for Vietnamese food in Soho and ended up at Pho,which is part of a small chain named after the Vietnamese national dish,in Wardour Street. It might have been our mistake to not actually go for the pho but instead order my usual triad of papaya salad,fresh spring rolls and Bun Cha. Whatever the reason,the food at Pho turned out to be the most westernised and least authentic Vietnamese I have had anywhere in London. Paired with rude and unpleasant service,I won't exactly hurry back. 1. The Papaya Salad Vietnamese papaya salad is one of my favourite dishes of all time and I take it personally when it is done badly. The papaya salad at Pho had only very remote resemblance to the versions I enjoyed in Vietnam or at the more authentic Vietnamese places in and around Kingsland Road in East London. As you can probably see on this picture,the salad consisted mostly of other vegetables,for example loads of yellow and red peppers,while being almost devoid of green papaya. Apart from the fact that I thoroughly dislike peppers,they don't have anything to do in a Vietnamese papaya salad! I would not have ordered the dish if it had been stated on the menu that it was really a red and yellow pepper/cucumber/carrot and a little bit papaya salad. In addition the salad lacked any kind of spice and was garnished only with some measly herbs. 2. Fresh Summer Rolls My rant continues. The fresh summer rolls mainly consisted of noodles and I didn't pick up any fresh herbs at all. For those of you who have never eaten Vietnamese I should mention that what makes Vietnamese dishes so distinctly delicious is the cornucopia of fresh herbs such as coriander,spear mint,fish mint,Vietnamese mint,Thai basil,Cockscomb Mint,etc etc. If you have tasted this delicate freshness once,you can never go back to a tuned down,westernised version. The peanut sauce was nice though. (here some picture and recipe on how summer rolls should look like) 3. Bun Cha The Bun Cha with lemongrass and chicken was ok,by no means great but certainly edible. Again the dish came with hardly any fresh herbs which just made it a bit bland. Here the rude waitress came into play. She didn't seem in a very good mood to begin with,and she asked us whether we wanted this dish spicy or not. Of course we wanted it spicy! The plate we got served was the mildest thing ever,so when we mentioned this to the waitress (thinking that maybe she got our order mixed up) she seemed positively annoyed,she just pointed to the table with the condiments and told us to put some chili oil on. I don't know how you feel,but I do prefer some fresh chili to chili oil. I really don't want to drown my healthy lunch in grease. If you have never had proper Vietnamese before,I am sure you will quiet enjoy Pho. The food is not bad per se,it is relatively cheap and the atmosphere and interior is actually really nice. For me however,Pho is just too far away from being authentic Vietnamese to get a lot of pleasure out of the food.

PtyECteFY6diHC1zdCOorw.text: I think the over all quality has gone down since I first started going here.  Also, probably my standards for pho have increased.  The staff here changes continually and some members are much better than others.  There is a lack on consistency in the quality of pho and portion sizes for takeaway.  Sometimes you get a very full tub of broth and a full container of noodles, chicken and sprouts and onions.  Other days the broth tub is less than half full and the amount of chicken, sprouts, noodles, and onion is very stingy.  (Sometimes there aren't any onions at all).  I have also gotten back to my office to discover a layer of oil on top of my broth which pretty much ruins the meal since there is no good way to get rid of all that oil.  I still go here on occasion because it is fast, relatively inexpensive and close to my office, but if I were looking for really good pho, this would not be the spot.  The broth is far blander than other places and the quality is hit or miss.

axGxTN2qD8Yu_WuX58fJ_g.text: This place is obviously very popular and was completely buzzing when we came here for lunch recently. The atmosphere is quite nice, as stated by other reviewers, and the service was excellent. The food, however, was a bit bleh - by no means bad, but also by no means exciting. I had the Mushroom and Veggie Pho and while it tasted fresh and healthy, it was also a little bland, and the mushrooms were rather few and far between. Nothing to write home about, if you ask me.

bf_CwbLNzgh_v6C9Enz4Bg.text: Ate lunch here today, on a day when all of Soho seemed to be wiped out by an apocalyptic virus (actually just a Bank Holiday after New Year). Despite the lack of movement on the streets, Pho Soho was hopping, to the point that around 1pm couples looking for a table were told there was a half hour wait (hint: give up if you are in a group!). We lucked in by getting a table by the window as soon as we walked in. I have to say that the staff are very well trained,  friendly, and just well organized. This is clearly a place that prided itself in service and it shows. As suggested by other reviewers the decor is pleasant and minimalist (bamboo table tops; wicker lighting shades on the walls; exposed brick). This was fine, but I would have been just as happy with formica table tops, florescent lighting, and surly service, if only the food was great. Which it wasn't. It was not terrible; but at the same time it certainly lacked any wow factor. I had a spicy mushroom and tofu pho, and while the spicing was OK, it wasn't particularly complex, and had none of the stronger notes you would expect from a good pho. The mushrooms, didn't taste particularly good; worse the accompanying cilantro was yellowing and a bit wilted, as were the bean sprouts (perhaps due to some sourcing problem over Christmas/New Year??). I wonder if the fact I am eating vegetarian/vegan fare makes my experience different from the other reviewers, but my honest thought is simply that the pho here is too westernised to really hit the mark. I am going to go looking in the Kingsland Road area for something a little rougher, pungent and more authentic.

SAWIboaTNnPdjhrv8rKgJg.text: Great service, fast and delicious beef pho with generous lean beef and extra vegetable if requested!

nyx0DXYvWoe6JajJW2OtJg.text: We ducked into the busy restaurant for lunch on Tuesday and were greeted by the most enticing aromas. Service was quick despite the crowd and we were enjoying our meal in minutes. We both ordered the tofu and mushrooms in veggie stock. With or without the add-ins, absolutely delicious!! I wish this was closer so I could eat here everyday. Fresh, easy and delectable... everything I want my lunch to be!

jEsy2izbvH3qcC_mV_LHsA.text: Fun and tasty Vietnamese restaurant with a simple menu. I loved the spicy noodle soup. Staff is fun and friendly too

IyRZyjiIwp65vq_J0Q1Qjg.text: i thought the bun was great. very gluten free friendly and affordable. i enjoyed the atmosphere too. recommend for a good gluten free lunch.

WIHbyKyelU99ChaYsMCp8w.text: Popped in Pho SOHO for a quick lunch and was served by a rather churlishly rude American hipster who didn't know the words 'please' or 'thank you'. He seemed surprised when I forgot the word 'Tip'.Food was above average but a bit mean.

rNXNUGoWJE-R7dHmUT5DBQ.text: TIIIIIIIINY portion of nbr 35 on the menu (stir fry chicken/prawn & noodles) we had to buy starters to complement. It was a bday party & they knew it, offered nothing to the bday girl, the service was really slow & the waitress spilled the stock on my skirt trying to clean the table hurriedly. OK to try as a one off, esp tha the place itself is lovely! but food is average really, which makes it overpriced.

e03J4yLE3oWj1qFeYgI1Sg.text: I ordered the Bun Cha Gio Chay (basically, vermicelli topped with vegetarian spring rolls and a ginger-soy sauce) and it was amazing. It was delicious and hit the spot. Not only was the food that I ordered great but the servers were friendly and the restaurant decor made me feel like I was eating away in someone's quaint brick-house (in a good way).

X2i3F3De6utA6c6Jo3jfTQ.text: I came here with some fellow yelpers to eat after Chinese (and Vietnamese!) New year celebrations in Chinatown. After a cold afternoon standing outside, we were ready for a warming noodle soup for sure! As there were 7 of us and they don't take bookings, it was an hour wait for a table, but we went early to get our names on a waiting list. Although it was busy and there wasn't much free space, the service was friendly and efficient. We all had summer rolls or the fried alternative, and pho or Vietnamese curry, all was very tasty!

UtlOy9j5hBsZIBNAwBJOSg.text: I'm not impressed with this chain. Maybe it varies quite a bit, but I've been there twice and probably won't go back. I like the decor, and the place is always booming. But despite these things, I think the food is "eh." The broth in my pho was unflavorful... just SALTY. You're better off making the trip to Shoreditch.

f-qYNyfDQ0wEgb8tpD_63Q.text: Oh Pho.So, so good. This little Soho venue, which controversially does feel like a luxury Vietnamese underground warren, is packed full of deliciousness and rather impressive staff.You'll probably be tempted in here on the promise of yummy pho. And you won't be wrong. But their other dishes are just as good, if not more so. I'm a huge fan of their bun noodles - a bowl of vermicelli noodles, salad, meat, sauce and a cheeky spring roll thrown in for good measure. Speaking of spring rolls, you'd be a fool not to have some for a starter, especially the pork ones.You can wash it all down with authentic Viet beers or one of their fruit smoothies.I went three times in a week. Enough said.

nmfKTSK9jnxb-XB9oBBBGg.text: I dropped by at Pho in Soho with Ms. Chocoholic for a quick bite before we had to rush off for other activities. No guessed that we ordered the classic Pho Tai £7.95. The first hit was a complexity of different herbs and spices that were amazing but after that, they seem to meld into an ending note where they seem to battle each other and tasted weird. I was definitely not keen on polishing off the soup at the end. Very much a anglo-sized version which will not please those who are looking for the real thing. Did I mention that the service was quite bad too? The staff were happily huddling away in a corner chilling out instead of paying attention to the diners.

xert_fw3W75zZlCHz2e0lA.text: This Pho was pretty overcrowded and didn't have much space to wait for a table BUT the service was great. Both before and during our meal we had great service and the food was, as expected, deeeelicious. We took my mom and introduced her both to Pho and to pho! Tasty.

j4jV6SY_ERksu88I_zzMhA.text: Pho in Soho!On my various trips to the USA, I've fallen in love with pho as an inexpensive but flavoursome meal option. However, on my return to the UK, my search for a similar level of pho-nomenon has been met with disappointment so far.I was therefore excited to find enthusiastic reviews from fellow Yelpers for this chain. I headed there for a late lunch on a Sunday afternoon.There were a healthy number of diners for the time of day. The menu is basic but had the required range of phos I was looking to sample.I started with the chicken goi cuon ga - summer rolls with chicken breast and herbs. Unfortunately, I found the wrapper a little thick, which made the dish heavy rather than light and zingy.I went the whole hog with the pho and chose the Pho Bo Dac Biet, which had brisket, steak and meatballs. For me, pho lives or dies with the soup and while acceptable, the soup here didn't have the depth of flavour of the best phos I've tasted. The meat content was OK and the meat was tender.Pho's food did taste like that of a chain restaurant, which is reasonable I suppose given that it is a chain restaurant! However, I still prefer the pho at Cam Phat just down the road in Chinatown, especially as it's cheaper.

ozMhPEnAc0OJ9pVyUf3hTg.text: MANGO SALAD. super fresh, super tangy, just amazing. the other dishes i've tried here were good as well, but seriously, do yourself a favor and get the mango salad. the menu describes it as "spicy" for some reason, but it's not at ALL so do not fear, just get it!!was packed on saturday evening, venue is small but comfortable. prices are decent, waitstaff better than london average attentive.

n4cKmbWBNJg_SYGQGbYhOg.text: While we were in London for a few hours we stopped by at what appeared to be a very popular Vietnamese restaurant (the place was packed!).  We had a car and had to park at a questionable spot, and therefore wanted to get a quick dinner and take off.  The staff was awesome, they managed to get us a table right away.  We ordered and our dinner was brought to our table promptly.  The food was great (explains why the place was packed). Would definitely go back if I happen to be in the area again.

PqvuDxW67ChDrVdvgGQ3pw.text: I love the food at Pho. I'm a regular customer of their restaurants all across London. I have been to Pho Wardour Street 3 times and every time I went there I was appalled by their lack of customer service and blatant rudeness. Some waitresses working there are extremely rude. They do not smile, they answer rudely, do not make eye contact and do not make you feel welcome at all. I won't be coming back again.

BLd2sUzuEDatJ-dUsMTm-Q.text: I'm not a pho expert, but my meal was excellent.  The fried pork spring roll starter is a must.  A resounding yes from all three of us who had them.  I then proceeded to have the Bun Ga Hue as I'm a sucker for spicy food.  Don't let the broth color intimidate you, it was not overpowering and actually mild.  Could have used some more meat in it, but all in all my taste buds thanked me. The reason for a 4 and not 5 simply was the length of wait for a table.  If you go as a party of 2, no problem.  They turn them over quite quickly.  Any more and you are looking at quite the wait.  It may have been the time we went, Monday dinner, or it may have just been the shear inaccuracy of their prediction (30 minutes turned into an hour) but I think the food is worth waiting for.Small print: most of my friends think I'm nuts for the heat I can handle so I'm not a very good judge.

zffpFFbq2I7y3GyytSOVLg.text: Our order consisted of prawn summer rolls, Vietnamese coffee, and beef vermicelli bowls. The summer rolls were OK, served with peanut sauce, but low on herbs. Coffee was fine. Vermicelli was a hot mess: "grilled" beef looked blanched and lacked any symptoms of ever being near a charcoal grill or, for that matter, a marinade, the noodles were thick Italian-style vermicelli (potentially half rice flour? certainly not pure rice) rather than rice stick vermicelli, the herbs consisted of one sprig of mint and three of cilantro, with no basil in sight, and the veg spring roll tasted stale, and was fried to the point of being a lethal weapon. Extra star only because ingredients did seem fresh, aside from the spring roll. You're in central London. Go elsewhere.

FVU6zQTKKRRgbNvvQHbwXg.text: the boyfriend said "we can come to London again for this." We live in Glasgow and we had pho in Vietnam and Southern California..etc. I'd have to say that they do an amazing job with the broth and the collection of herbs and condiments. for the noodles, I prefer mine to be well done instead of the al dente noodles I got. but all was well and we're going home happily.

esVeo1fS2w3SaJORCn9SGw.text: Pho is an exciting new chain that has opened in a few locations around London and in Brighton. It joins the new wave of Far East Asian fusion/modern eateries; Busaba Eathai (Thai), Wagamama (Japanese), Ping Pong (Dim Sum/Chinese).This indeed, is like a Vietnamese version of Busaba Eathai or Wagamama. A lot of the food is similar to them like the Pho Noodle Soup (like Chilli Ramen or the choice of tea, similar to Ping Pong (e.g. the flower tea that never fails to amaze some patrons, as if they're watching a David Blaine video)In case you didn't know, Vietnamese food is similar to Thai food, with French influence (previous colonial rulers).If you order the Pho Noodle Soup,  they may indeed offer you a bib, as the other review said. I think they must offer it to the most in need, since like the other reviewer, i'm pretty sure I was the only patron eating with a bib. Not very cool when eating out, but then again, not very cool splashing Pho Noodle soup on your white shirt, unless you're going for a tie dye look.I must say, it was very cosy, and intimate, something unusual for the recent trend 'nu-wave' of far east asian eateries. So I recommend it as a fun, urban, 'cool' place to go , especially if you're a Vietnamese novice.Obviously, if you're looking for traditional authentic Vietnamese food, you may wish to try alternatives, but I personally highly recommend Pho, if you're in a small group/couple.

tciQwxnKeYIGNk6w8kBSew.text: I love the dark and labyrinthine vibe here with lanterns and wooden walls etc. it's cool, and the little entrance is just great. I'm a bit of a snob about chains but I have enjoyed two visits to Pho. The Pho itself isn't super authentic but it is delicious. The salads were perfect for a hot spring day and I left feeling as if my soul had been revitalised.

T8LPpLT0TPInGeuJNw3ZBg.text: Boyfriend and I had to dine and dash from Pho because we had tickets for a show in the West End (less than 20 mins from ordering).  Our waitress was very accommodating and allowed us to pay our bill even before our food arrived so we'll just be able to eat our meal and get on our way.  Bf was such a trooper - he ate his grilled chicken vermicelli in less than 15 mins...luckily my homemade beef ball pho (2 stars...beef balls were dry and not very tasty) wasn't overly hot so I was able to match the speed he was eating.  Ha.  Call it bad planning, but maybe if we had more time to look over the menu and order something that took a bit more time to make we would've enjoyed what we ordered more.  I'd give the intimate space a 4 for decor though.  Btw, bf wanted to eat at the Indian tapas place next door but I whined about having too much spiced food of late.  Serves me right.

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom

oHgucRxCcF4YwbUV3IGFjg.text: Pics@Chopstix2Steakniveschopstix2steaknives.blog…I dropped by at Pho in Soho with Ms. Chocoholic for a quick bite before we had to rush off for other activities. No guessed that we ordered the classic Pho Tai £7.95. The first hit was a complexity of different herbs and spices that were amazing but after that, they seem to meld into an ending note where they seem to battle each other and tasted weird. I was definitely not keen on polishing off the soup at the end. Very much a anglo-sized version which will not please those who are looking for the real thing. Did I mention that the service was quite bad too? The staff were happily huddling away in a corner chilling out instead of paying attention to the diners.

OTiGmob9VDSNHZV6PC65Eg.text: For a place named after Pho....their Pho is just meh. What is delicious however are the prawn summer rolls. Peanut sauce always, none of that sweet-chilli nonsense! Order the bun noodles for a much tastier alternative. You have to either come really early or really late to get a seat if you don't want to wait for an hour, which seems to be the norm for weeknights. Its really affordable but honestly....Wardour Street has so many awesome eateries that its not worth the wait if there is one! Hop out of the que and window shop the amazing Soho restaurants next-door for an equally fabulous meal thats just that little bit quicker.

wuulr1K_iaFRe5MvCJIpxQ.text: No self-respecting Vietnamese would eat what passes for pho from here.  The broth is not pho in any sense of that dish.  Urgh!

yZqaw2h8Y9kOvsB1Ha2aTQ.text: I ended up having a late lunch here since Papaya was out of Pad Thai and I was craving noodles. I checked out the menu before walking in and saw that one third of their menu was pho noodle soup which is always a good sign for a Vietnamese restaurant. The decor is done in dark tones with exposed brick walls and red ceilings. There were only two other people eating so service was fast. I ordered the pho with beef slices and brisket. My food came out pretty quick and although it looked good, the flavors were bland. Adding hot sauce and oyster sauce helped the soup but not the tasteless beef and flat noodles. (Why didn't they mention that they serve the pho with flat rice noodles? I thought it was standard to serve it with the thin ones.) Overall the food was average but pricey. You're definitely paying for the ambiance. You can go to any hole in the wall Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco and find much better pho.

F8lut9Pc_fTb75zZnTpyiw.text: If this were Inception, and I were floundering in my subconscious (on a Monday morning most likely), then this would be my 'kick' back to reality  PHO  and it's Bun Bo Hue, or spicy beef noodle soup.It is the best bloody thing IN THE WORLD after a long weekend How many times it has saved my soul I cannot recall, but know this, I have more lives than a cat.Seriously though, if you're in Soho, and need a spicy 'kick' to bring you back to reality then look no further. Hands down the best pho in town. And if you don't like beef, there are other options. Not for me though..I had one yesterday, and I'm having another one today. :)

B5D0Q_c74TEdCGTJS3TbiQ.text: Quick courteous service with nice staff ...so far tried the Pho Bo Combo and the Curry with Chicken and king prawn ...now, I'm not too sure how to rate the food in comparison to Vietnamese spots in England, however, it was so-so as I've had way better in the US ...might try again

MqQQjtuTeokncwbvmmQG7w.text: The food is not authentic nor any good for that matter. Anyone looking for real Vietnamese should pass. I would give zero stars if I could because of the high prices for such crap foo-foo food.Pho - not the right kind of noodles, meat sliced too thick and not allowed to cook in the broth so it was overcooked. Broth was extremely bland as well. A good pho broth is made from boiling bones for several hours to get that rich flavor -- this was no better than water.Vermicelli bowl (bun) with beef - bland bland bland. I don't even want to spend any more time on this but again, wrong technique with the meat. This traditionally would be served with grilled pork with a sweet glaze rather than the beef or chicken offered.

FdG7N8a5TYCV-nWPZuWu0A.text: Modernized chain Vietnamese is still my favorite!I've eaten at a few Vietnamese restaurants in London and elsewhere, but Pho is still my favorite for the namesake dish: Pho! I always pho ga and summer rolls. Fabulous! I've also tried the bun and was quite impressed. It's good fresh food, though service is often lacking.

dc8FrGzmHQbWVDWLJ31obg.text: I met up with old friends that I can not seen in ages this past Monday.I quickly realized that it was not the most conducive place for having a good chat. The Soho location at least was INCREDIBLY crowded.Further the layout and design of the restaurant made it completely difficult to be able to easily navigate through the tight space between tables. People were standing around the 4X4 area that was the bar.Further they were blasting the heat at nuclear fusion levels and it was quite uncomfortable just sitting!The staff was quite friendly and accommodating, and the food was just fine but not great or amazing in the least.Overall the experience was pretty average, if not a bit on the uncomfortable side and therefore I cannot say that I would frequent Soho again.

VuTFXl_aRaA-zpsOKG__oQ.text: The Chicken pho was delicious!  I really enjoyed my meal here and I can't wait to come back again.  The pho itself is pretty spicy, and it seemingly gets spicier towards the end of your dish.  If you are nervous for spice, be wary in adding the fresh chillies that come along as a side to your pho!  Those little chillies are way spicier than you think!Anyways, this place gets super busy and packed, but it's cosy and a great place to catch up with friends or family.

Esps3MkuqLLtVu85phmnow.text: Awesome pho. Super large bowls.When we visited, this place was teeming with customers, there was almost nowhere to sit and wait for a table. We waited about 45mins. Make sure you try the morning glory appetizer! I wanted fresh rolls but somehow they were so busy that they were all out. That was a bummer.They play good music as well.

MWBpExj1bExQvYXTXwq2sw.text: I like the vibe here, I really do. The confusing way you enter straight into the dining room blasting the first table with a breeze however so cold and then would seemingly have to go to the rear of the restaurant to flag down a waiter/waitress to be seated. I am not accustomed to this practice but already in my few short weeks as a London newcomer I am noticing that this is fairly common. It's quirky like that, but cool nonetheless in all its confusingness (see what I did there?). I also found it to be unbearably hot, like 25 degrees but that aside, service was attentive and fun, and I sweated not so noticeably on an otherwise fine night. The food was a little bit of a let down if I'm going to be honest. I eat pho on a regular at many different restaurants, and have dined in many of them from California to Budapest and what this Pho serves, while being creative and ample in terms of its numerous options, falls short of that authentic Vietnamese earth moving, soul invigorating goodness.NOTE TO THE CHEF: Use rice noodles (bánh pho). You cannot call it "pho" otherwise.

x_azqywWCEex3w-kg9I2aw.text: Came here and got the brisket pho and had a much better experience.  The meat was tender and tasted great.  I knew the time I went and didn't like the meatballs would be a fluke, but I'm still skittish about ordering them again.

oPFifvTfYrU9LlEOzcwqFw.text: Soups and service are great. Calamari is spicy delight. Great casual meal. Nothing fancy. Great hangover cure.

zgmNAmcmjBdmtjkgq03mmQ.text: Feeling little homesick on my trip backpacking Europe so I had to find me some Vietnamese food. Soup was on point, especially with the weather in London. Totally worth the walk from Piccadilly Square. Would recommend.

D7qq9USq04n7txw14oHSMQ.text: Only been here once but it was one of the best veggie cà-rii ever had !! With decent prices level and great staff. It also have nice atmosphere, tables spaced out well, and great music in acceptable volume. I'm so happy we found it :)

Ig4gru5t3PQFUu0-YS3TGg.text: First time trying pho. Must say I loved it.  I love being able to control the spice and adding the bean sprouts. Cilantro etc. I ORDERED THE HOT & spicy prawns. Highly recommended. Also ordered the spring rolls. Very fresh. Nothing to die over though!

niQSs78eFqoj4j4EtvlN2Q.text: On "holiday" from California, my best friend and I ate here. We really enjoyed it. The waitress was very nice and recommended our dishes which were yummy. The "Pho" soup we ordered was a bit bland, but the curry and appetizer made up for it. It was really good and a nice atmosphere for a lunch/dinner spot. Mmm

JMZ66B6fOwZ1qQ_1TlmAzg.text: Today I ate lunch wearing a bib. After taking my seat and ordering my favourite bowl of pho for a lovely lunch with Vikki C, our eyes carefully spied the paper and plastic joys that the waitress unfolded and handed to us. Erm... right!Never fear though, we bravely donned the protective garments getting full involved in our steam hot bowls of Vietnamese goodness.  Actually, wearing my favourite Cath Kidtson dress today I was actually very gratefully for the bib. I might even see if they sell them in bulk. I know my dad could do with some of them, and it would save my Mum a lot of time in washing his shirts.Pho, you clever people, great soup, great bibs!

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom

8hcgCKWNnQYkrLqq__AD7g.text: Great Pho. Servers much more friendly and welcoming than in other branches! The food did take a while (about 3 parties came in after the two of us and got their food before we did), but it was worth the wait :)

NLHatBfaVz-rVGVqTaWjZQ.text: Came with a friend at a cold night. We discovered this place totally by accident. This place is hidden in a small street near Oxford st. I was attracted by its atmosphere. We ordered spring roll and beef noodle soup. The spring roll was great! The noodle soup was standard. (according to US standard)I would totally hangout with friends here if I lived in London.

wc-l79ujgmtiTmKij81bAw.text: If you don't have to wait for an hour to be seated... (which happens after about 7 most nights these days...) this place is great.VERY affordable Soho dinner.The biggest problem is anticipating what the worst food envy will be on the table dependant on opting for a pho bowl, fried noodles, rice or curry dish.Vietnamese coffee is stellar, and though quite pricey- it does come 'properly' served with the 'Phin filter' on top percolating richly spice-infused caffeine onto a handsome dollop of condensed milk. Can't do without one, every time.Last time I ventured here, their gas stopped working halfway through the night and we had to wait over an hour to get our food in the end. However- they did tell us immediately and brought us a selection of summer rolls to snack on and without us even complaining, cut our £60 bill to £25. Wow. Go Pho!

Rpp4nIl5DLVwuHPZYrFpjg.text: Good service, cosy environment, pleasant staff and quick service too without feeling rushed. Decent prices too and the portion sizes are generous, well worth a visit

V6d2II9xNIRrgekzsY9U_A.text: I've popped into Pho Soho a few times when I couldn't think of anywhere else to go, and it's always a great shout. The restaurant itself is quite cramped, but if you don't mind being a little up close and personal with people personally I think it ads to the atmosphere. The staff are always lovely, the food is great value for money and theres veggie option as well as meat and fish- something for everyone. Try the Kari. It's great!

YUdralTTvx0o8zXs95Doig.text: I know the place is called Pho. But forget the pho. Go for the bun noodles. For a special treat, order the summer rolls with peanut sauce to start. And remember to use the sriracha. Pho is a perfectly inoffensive and sterilised introduction to Vietnamese cuisine for Westerners - that also happens to be pretty cheap. And sometimes that's just what you need.

V_lWl6wSGP7UQiSqUxSmYA.text: Continuing our drinking trek about Soho, it was time to stop for dinner. On this cold, blustery February night, I've chosen Pho to warm up with a steaming bowl of Pho. I made my choice after messaging fellow Yelper from London Meena R. Pho's atmosphere is nice and cozy, with upbeat (slightly loud) music. After a 15 minute wait we were seated. We began with apps of Em Hai San ( a delicious roll of prawn, crab, and pork), Summer rolls, and Muc chien gion (squid in lime juice, surprisingly good as I'm not a big squid fan) Our Pho selections were the steak, and the Combo (steak, brisket and meatball). All were very delicious and satisfyingly filling. The food's a 5 star here, I've rated Pho a 4 due to cramped conditions (got jostled about during the 15 minute wait) a bit of server inattentiveness, and the overly loud music made it a bit hard to converse. The food itself is definitely recommended and is worth a return visit. Thanks again, Meena!!

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Steak pho
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Muc chien gion (squid in lime juice)
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Combo pho (steak, brisket & meatball)

9NsWoxpjzRiLsNewyW8HUA.text: Food: Their pho broth was good, but not the best I've had. Their noodles ... OH! Their noodles ... tasted like plastic. The shame. They were either packaged noodles or frozen and thawed. So disappointed. I got the pho with the brisket and meatballs. Their meatballs were delicious -- made with meat and lemongrass. Customer Service: Excellent, attentive waiter. Good job on this one.Restaurant: Quite characteristic, but in terms of customer appeal, this place relies more on its central location than the quality taste of its food. Their pho isn't terribly bad; it's just not as good as other pho restaurants (like the Shoreditch area).

2sBIXKqbR3jzEiWrFwJ5Qg.text: Amazing vibe, delicious food and super friendly stuff.!!! Everyone should come here and try Vietnamese food.I've traveled Vietnam and the food here reminds me old times.!

g5FjbuvH37eQt0DK7FKgBA.text: One of the best Pho bowls I've had in a long time.  This place fills up quickly, but I would say it's worth the wait! The spicy brisket beef was good and and combination with meatballs was tasty. Our food was out in less than 15 minutes.

VRgpgdQ1HSn2FPVJqv2fZw.text: I just want to warn everybody who want to go there, that this is a very unfriendly place and the pho tasted bad the beef tasted strange . The table was so dirty and I will never go there again......

6q5hkCDw7JbHXGzitpbMZg.text: Best pho ever!!! Ever place I travel to I like to try their local foods as well as the pho (if they have it). This was the best pho by far!! Great place, drinks, and atmosphere. And if you want a, chilling, place to have a drink you can go around the corner to The Ten Bells Pub where Jack the Ripper once stood and got his two victims....Chilling.

tdzgiZXg6SS358Jw_dBYfA.text: It's in Soho,go down streets 2block from main road.I fond signboard"PHO".I interested this restaurant.It was like Vietnamese and dark.I thought English made good atmosphere well.Full scale menu,it was written Vietnamese.I didn't know name "Phoga",but I was able to order.It came few min.I wasn't able to wait long time.Looked great.few kind of Veg and it was not small.I had ever eaten real pho!Server is very friendly.I'm really glad to came here on foot.It tooks  20mins.

aIT1eeHHfPSRYbI2rleAvg.text: Having been to Pho a few times now, I know what to expect and I know what I like here. So while it might not be the most authentic place to get pho, I enjoy it for what it is!Personally I'm not a big fan of soup so I don't ever get pho. My other half does though and loves it (a tip - ask for a bib if you're having soup, or just a messy eater!). I tried some of his last time we went and I really, really didn't like it - but I think that's down to me and nothing to do with the food.I always get the Pho Xao with beef for a main, and we get an order of summer rolls to share. This time they brought peanut sauce with the summer rolls and it was even better than the normal sauce I usually have.Strangely my noodles came with chicken. I'm pretty sure I ordered beef but hey, I like chicken, so I ate it and didn't complain. Plus it's always possible I misordered...The service was fine, food quick, and all in all, a pleasant meal.

IU4p8v-jrGGTXyvq_WKZqA.text: I've been to a different Pho outlet once before, and I have to say as someone who has never been to Asia and whose entire culinary experience of its foods have been through restaurants serving its foods in other continents - I thoroughly enjoy Pho.The waiting staff were good, although I always prefer if they write down an order. The food came quickly and was very tasty. I was scared that Pho wouldn't live up to the memory of my first trip but it more than did, partly due to some great air con on a very warm day. Can't wait for my next visit.

Uo4LE2WZuKxvizBp2-GX-g.text: Don't go for the pho. It's not great, but if you're sickly and need a soup... sure The pho didn't have the depth of flavour that a traditional pho has. I will have to go again and try something else.

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Banana fritter with a delicious coconut ice cream.
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Strawberry and basil sorbet

--VtPk8rIGn5FH9wgQtLOw.text: I've been to this branch of Pho a few years ago and hadn't come back in ages since then. Yesterday afternoon I was desperately looking for a restaurant that had quite filling dishes with low calories as I am currently on a very strict diet, and a friend suggested I had a look at Pho's. I was honestly surprised to see so many dishes with so few calories, but I thought that they'd probably be quite smallish dishes that'd leave me hungry for more. I couldn't be more wrong. I've had the Ph nm rm: , a rice-noodles soup with enoki, shiitake and  button mushrooms. Chose the vegetable stock instead of the chicken stock: 376 Kcal. Admittedly, I wouldn't usually order anything that doesn't have meat or fish in it and I was expected quite a bland taste from this dish. Sweet baby Jesus was I wrong. It was so packed full of flavours, the soup comes served with a mini-tray of raw extra herbs to add to it, as well as some cheeky SUPER EXTRA MEGA HOT chili peppers. I left with a full tummy and was very happy with the experience throughout, I only wish the tables & seats for two were a teeny tiny bit more comfortable and spacious. Will definitely go back next time I fancy a guilt-free dinner out.

o0R8mpczjJitBOpZLqbU9w.text: Oh dear... Ok let me start off by saying that I DO fancy myself a pho expert and I am very surprised by the great reviews this place has. My husband and I were meandering the streets of SoHo upon arriving in London, my eyes fixated on the Pho sign and he knew that was our final destination. The decor was nice, dark and casual, with exposed red brick and wooden tables lit with candles, which created a nice mood for a restaurant, and definitely nicer than the majority of pho places I've ever been too.The staff was super friendly, but painfully slow. We were seated in the window seat by the door. We waited a good 10 minutes before anyone gave us menus. It took another 10 minutes for them to take our order!  I was a little leery when I had to correct the waitress's horrendous butchering if the menu items. After we were able to place our order, we had to flag someone down to remind them that we didn't get our drinks yet, and then again when they brought the wrong drinks! We also notice during all of this waiting that our original server had left for the day!  I'm glad we flagged someone else down, else we would have been there ALL day!I had the pho dac diet, which had no tripe or tendon, this is a cardinal sin of authentic pho, you can not call it Dac Biet without the two! The pho noodles were huge flat fettuccini sized rice noodles. I really didn't like this modified version of my favorite comfort food. The broth was watery and overly bland! My husband ordered the bun ga, which again was not made with vermicelli noodles, but of a much thicker udon size noodle! (Umm, not even Vietnamese!) I just couldn't understand the patrons filtering in for this place. It couldn't be the food! This place albeit cute, is a gross misrepresentation of what Vietnamese cuisine should be, maybe it should be called an 'interpretation' of pho restaurant. The staff needs to really focus on service and less on each other, they all congregated in the back when I walked by, no one else seemed to be as annoyed as we were, but i don't believe anyone was in a hurry either.Sorry yelpers, I don't want to be overly critical, but I was most definitely underwhelmed by the whole experience. I hope this isn't what people think Vietnamese food tastes like this!! It sooo doesn't! Pho is very overpriced for what it offered! This place needs to focus more on the service and the food rather than dumping money into the ambiance, I don't know anyone that comes to a restaurant for ambiance without the other two components in play.

P0xpJZFMvgbEr5AB5xWnLw.text: Similar to all other locations. Average food, inconsistent and pricey for what you get as a Vietnamese food. Good for a first diner and if you are hungry and don't matter the taste.

gLH9svBuxgofhCFXVnRBMA.text: Aside from the bitch who served us (didn't smile once, was pretty rude, and didn't write our order down, in turn giving us spring rolls instead of summer rolls -luckily they were AMAZING), our meal was really nice, and i'll probably return. I had a really nice pineapple and coconut smoothie, with the spring rolls (seriously tasted incredible with the peanut sauce), and a tofu noodle soup. The tofu was awesome.. some of the best I've had. The atmosphere was lovely.. ambient, chilled and casual. It's a shame that as we were starting to put our coats on, a pair of seat vultures came through the door and bluntly said "are you leaving?" and continued to make their move, despite us still sitting down, but you can't have it all, I guess.. had to hurry to get out of the door because i'd had enough rudeness projected my way that day. Ugh.EDIT:I've decided Pho do the best spring rolls I've ever had. Teamed with the peanut sauce they're just amazing. On our last visit we had a creamy coconut broth. It was literally incredible. They also gave us a bunch of complimentary summer rolls... what! I LOVE PHO.

-hv_OKRENK2FJYrCrcCsPw.text: Decided on Vietnamese while in Soho, and this seems to be of lower pricing compared to the competitors nearby. I wanted a more authentic experience versus the others nearby, which were more fusion. Also, I was craving for pho, and it supposed to be a cheap street food, I wasn't keen to pay more just because they served it on a fancier plate, smaller portion and decorated fancier and charge you a premium for that. Overall, the taste is very average, nothing special. The noodles were obviously taken out of the fridge very recently, as it wasn't piping hot, and it was still was quite stick together, ie. not stirred and cooked properly long enough. So, it had that mass produced factory plasticky taste to it. Fresh flat rice noodles should be slick, smooth and really soft. The broth was tasty, and the usual side of bean sprouts and greens were there. Though, I did return home with a headache an hour later. I attribute it to the usual high MSG content, many pho Vietnamese restaurants (a common feature globally) use in their soups. We arrived after 9pm, and it was still busy; we were waiting for a table for 15 minutes, which isn't uncommon for Soho restaurants. Ambiance was okay, though a tad dark for my taste. Service was excellent, as we were waited on by a really friendly and enthusiastic lady. However, our food was brought over by a different, rather impatient and grumpy lady. Reading the reviews here before coming over, I could see how many have complained about the poor service - if you were served/waited on by this other waitress. The fresh spring roll with prawns were good. The pandan flavoured pancake with desiccated coconut with ice-cream was a bit disappointing; it's obvious it's made elsewhere, as it tastes rubbery as if it's been made a long time ago and preserved. Pricing is decent in this part of London. For two bowls of pho, a starter, a dessert and two beers, it came to £40.

zdCxzF_QMwTI1Asq7aAM1Q.text: It would not be fair to give a four star to a restaurant that I doubt I'd be coming back. even if the food here is not bad and the ambiance is a pretty cool and hip soho joint.In fact, their appetizer called Banh Xeo Tom Ga, a traditional Vietnamese crepe filled with prawns, chicken and beansprouts was absolutely delis . The quantity was not so bad for a little less than £8. Their Prawn crackers for £2.5  though, was stale and unappealing and really should be given out for free.  Most of the mains are approximately £8 - £10:- Their Pho Xao, which is stir-fried flat noodles are pretty good as well. - The Pho Bo Hue, which is hot and spicy brisket beef soup (served with a chilli shrimp paste) is bland and unappealing overall, and there was almost no meat in it.-Their Buns look amazing, though I didn't try. I was told there is also no meat.Why I would not go back? Well it's high prices for low quantity overall. The noodles were very unfilling and I'd much rather go to an actual Vietnamese-run restaurant in Chinatown or elsewhere than a hip Soho joint. I've had much better vietnamese food for lower prices.Also, note that their food is not spicy at all, even if you ask for it super spicy. They also do not have any rice selection besides curry.Overall, I say the quality of the food is decent, a little on the expensive price, and the quantity is small. The ambience is quite nice though. Don't get pho noodle soup and you'll be fine.

zpbdgpD2Us9xxRJBzU0YnQ.text: The broth of the Phô was sooo good! The location is good especially if you wouldn't like to go to a packed place in cental

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. PHO combo

4WUllG5O80R0ZLNkc_rN8A.text: I don't even know if I'm reviewing the right place but oh well lol.. The seafood pho I ate last week was worth a review! It took me to my favourite place ... Flavour town! And left me wondering how I could recreate the damn thing! Squid was a little rubbery but I can't complain because sometimes I cook it that way too ... Noones perfect huh .... Only thing I'd say is there were hardly any noodles in my bowl... It was pure broth! Man can't survive alone on broth you know! Anyhoo delicious and defo worth visiting

UgTPIfInxtv2DmGJ79AS-Q.text: Met up my friends for lunch on a busy bank holiday Sunday. Waiter was apologetic that no table was available but after around 10mins got seated. Most of us tried the pho while I decided to try the veggie spring rolls ban (vermicelli) Drinks came pretty rapidly (definitely recommend the refreshingly zesty iced tea) Unfortunately we waited for nearly half an hour before getting our orders, despite a group nearby arriving 15 mins after we did and got their food first. Another waiter (long blonde, tied back hair guy) served our orders and told explained about the condiments accompanying the pho, warning it could be very spicy. At the same time my friend, who has a high tolerance for spicy food, dumped all his condiments into his bowl. The waiter rudely said to him "are you listening?" before shortly walking away. Unbelievable! My fiance had the 3 mushrooms pho which were a little bland but my veggie spring rolls ban was mouthwateringly delicious! Definitely would recommend the ban and to dip in the soy sauce accompanying it too. Price was reasonable for the food and central location. Although the ban was good, the long wait and rude waiter tainted the overall experience.

tZvCBhrSz-2cX8u1fWQSBg.text: Faux-pho. That's what it felt like for me. I had heard a lot about Vietnamese food and walking by on a cold and rainy day with a sore throat, this called out to me. I thought a hot soup was exactly what I needed so why not try it Vietnamese style.I ordered the Pho Ga with chicken broth and chicken breast and added button mushrooms to it  (they let you mix and match your pho specifications even if it's not on the menu which is nice too) because it seemed like a failsafe way to ease into a new cuisine. When it came, the broth was pretty watery and tasteless and the entire dish was bland. I didn't enjoy the mushrooms either. I've heard Vietnamese broth has depth, but this had none.  It makes me glad I had that sore throat, otherwise I would have gotten no pleasure whatsoever out of this dish. The spring rolls were okay, very mediocre and nothing special. My friend had the spicy chicken pho and that was much better than mine, but still wasn't impressive in any way. After awhile I did try to spice mine up with the strong garlic chili sauce on the table, but even though it's a decent sauce, it couldn't save the lack of broth flavor.  The best I can say for this place was that the pineapple mocktail was not bad. The place itself is small and crowded, but if you're just two people you can probably get a table without a wait, like I did. It's got a very hip feel to it, with wicker lamps and one side of the tiny room having a brick wall and the other wooden. I think the biggest problem here is the service. The waitress seemed friendly at first but then made a lot of mistakes and didn't seem to care. We had to ask two different waitresses for spoons because the first just plonked down the plates of pho without giving us spoons or the plate of accompanying herbs and bean sprouts that they serve it with and then didn't bother to come back. After waiting awhile we asked a second waitress who also ran away without acknowledging us and finally came back and dumped two spoons with herb plates on our table as quick as she could so she could leave. I know they're busy but it's a bit odd not to have anyone care about giving you a utensil while your food gets cold. The waitress also got our orders wrong. She brought us a prawn chip appetiser as well which we didn't order (but since we like prawn chips we didn't mention it and decided to keep it). She also got my friend's order wrong and brought chicken pho instead of prawn and flat noodles instead of bun noodles. When we told her, she went and got her notepad so she could show us that she had written down the number for the chicken pho (which we didn't order but she didn't believe us) and my hungry friend gave up and kept the order we had. Verdict: Not a fan

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Spicy chicken pho

U1ZZytWxjN4V-zrl2Q82Gw.text: This a great place to go to for dinner and drinks. Dark ambience with great music. The servers are all friendly. We got veggie spring rolls and those were crunchy and delicious. The wrap wasn't too doughy and overbearing. I didn't care for the peanut sauce that came with it. It was more like peanut butter than anything else. The Pho was good. It came with all the usual fixings. If I ever find myself in that area again, I would definitely go Back.

1hel3ox8oV_BUF-MLXSoTQ.text: If I could give this place a -5 stars I would. What to say.... I don't understand how this place to get so many positive reviews when I wouldn't even feed this to my dog.  I would consider animal cruelty.It was dark it was dingy it was like an oven and they didn't even want to turn on the air-conditioner because we had to ask them. They begrudgingly agreed. I had pho and the roast beef was a chunk it was overcooked. There were two chunks of beef in my bowl.  The noodles were all wrong for the type of dish. I had disgusting chunky meaty spring roll that was lukewarm. The worst part about it was that my friend ordered a vermicelli bowl with chicken which is one of the easiest things to prepare and they couldn't even make that right. Not to mention she ended up with food poisoning for the rest of the night. It completely ruined the entire day and evening and we are only here visiting for a couple of days. The best part of the experience was getting our check and walking out the door.

p60I8490BdkBDP8YiNxLRA.text: Everytime we walked by, we always smell a strong broth. So for the first time, we stopped by for an early dinner, since I was craving for comfort food. The stars are given for the ambience. I loved the atmosphere in the restaurant, but not so much of the food. As a foodie, I have eaten at many pho restaurants including in Vietnam. So, I do have some expectations for my noodles. Firstly, and most importantly, there was no taste in the broth - very very disappointing since you smell it walking by. Secondly, the noodles used, is not what is normally used for authentic pho. It was thicker which are usually used by the Chinese, not Vietmanese. In addition, the noodles tasted like it came out from a package. Next, the pho I asked for was the Hanoi beef with garlic. There was no garlic taste and the beef was soooooo tough. My jaw was tired after the bowl of noodles. No exaggeration. The other two bowls of pho my friends had were no different...We also tried the fried pork roll (which was meh.. and the sauce which came with it was really made to fit British taste buds rather than authentic...) and the morning glory with garlic. The highlight of the night was the morning glory - which is like steamed with garlic on top... Very simple. So unfortunately, I was extremely disappointed. The smell was like false advertisement. Pretty sure I won't be back. Oh btw, they add a pound to your bill for charity without asking. I don't mind donating but I don't like how it's just added on.

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom

M-38SV7PSa1gwI5Hn6I0fQ.text: I'm from California and there is an abundant amount of Pho restaurants which is why my review may seem harsh, but there are still so many things that are inexcusable for this "Pho" restaurant. I gave it at-least a 2 star because the presentation of the restaurant is very nice, and if you're taking someone who is ignorant to the experience of quality Pho you can at-least give off the impression that this is a nice and fancy Vietnamese restaurant. Came here at night right after landing from my flight and was really craving asian food for some reason. This place was near where I was staying and it looked nice so I thought to give it a try. The service was very slow and the servers just gave off this weird pretentious attitude when I was asking about the menu. I ordered Pho and spring rolls, I figured I was at a Vietnamese restaurant called "Pho" and these are basic Vietnamese dishes so they must be good here. I was disappointed with my Pho and Springrolls,  basically the food was expensive and it wasn't that good.

8kyGbBd5lpZ5JEy5Aa3Fuw.text: Got the veggie spring roll bun which came warm and then overwhelmed by the dressing. Not very nice.

pPwOfhp1Ra7SQdMh0PScNw.text: Came during lunch time to try this place out. The atmosphere of the place is probably the best part of this place. Super affordable and service is good but the food is very lackluster. Some specialty dishes not found at other places but they have most of the regular soup items and dishes. They served a little bit thicker noodles than what I am used to but it was more authentic so I dont mind that they give it their best try. They did not skim out the beef scum so I had nasty collection of beef scum in my soup. The soup was just missing something.. I had to add sriracha sauce and extra lime to make it edible. (Usually I dont put anything in my soup)This place does not have Hoison sauce but does have some chili peppers.

PHCpLkEN97VvrPu2M8rXbQ.text: Had a craving for some Pho so I headed to the nearest Pho place with the best Google reviews.  I was expecting some mind blowing pho to be served here since it had good reviews.  In my mind I had a vision that a Vietnames lady with an English accent will take my order.  Nope. It was a non Asian person who took my order.  I was surprised how hip this place was. Imagine BRC mixed with The smell of Pho Saigon.  Yum.  The food came out and it looked like a legit bowl of pho. I was excited so I do my typical ritual of squirting some Srirarcha and Hoisin together, but there was no Hoisin .  Damn. Strike one.  I took a sip of the broth. Bland AF. Strike two. I bit into a Bo Vien.  It had the texture of a spaghetti meatball.  It wasn't firm.  Strike three.  This is not how you do pho London!!  No! I wanted to really like this place, but if fell flat.  Will not be going back

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom

2U92M96zl5f2oGc3gYfJGQ.text: Delicious pho and fried spring roll (prawn).  The broth was tasty and the beef brisket was flavorful. The sprint roll was great as well, crispy and yummy inside. The one wish I had was for there to be Hoisen sauce (which maybe a very American side).  I ate the entire bowl either way. I went on a Thursday night around 7:30pm and there was a wait roughly 20 min. Not bad but there's no one who tells you wait time nor place that's clear it's the start of the queue... staff was busy and didn't offer to clarify. However once seated the service was great.So... food delicious, service nice, wait time expected. Make a guess on where to queue front or back pending others I suppose.

HxCjkWjii5ifnGd3yZUMaQ.text: Nice ambience, fast and friendly service. Spring rolls were good, so was the peanut sauce. Pho came with a lot of meat, but too little rice noddles. If you're used to traditional Pho, their Pho is actually very disappointing. The steak was too thick (though I won't fault them for giving a lot) and the meatballs lack the springy texture of traditional Pho. Their meatballs were more like what you would eat with spaghetti. The soup wasn't flavourful either, and there wasn't any hoisin sauce to help it.If you're looking for Pho, it's probably better to find some hole in the wall restaurant. That's what I'll be doing.

EYbkwqhAezeraeUAYkyudQ.text: Great service and great Pho in the Soho area.  We dropped in off the street for a quick lunch and wasn't disappointed with the Pho (with meat) and appetizers.

a4rbU9lrb69rQCTXreeyaA.text: Our group dropped in for nice hot bowls of noodle soup after a trek through the rain drenched streets in the Soho district.  The servers were very friendly and welcoming; they even offered to hang up our wet rain gear!  We were promptly seated at a table and they brought us a very fragrant and comforting jasmine tea.   The fried rice paper spring rolls were delicious.  I ordered the rice noodle soup with enoki mushrooms and tofu.  The chicken based broth really hit the spot!   Service is fast and efficient as well.    This is definitely a great place to go right before you see a show!

1-aGxep_Di5vmgAtk93dMw.text: I love love love love Pho. This is one of my fav places in London for no fussy Asian food. My husband loves pho too. I have been here multiple times and for lunch as well as dinner. The quality of service as well as food is great. The meatball Pho which is their classic is so good that I find it hard to have anything else every time I go there. One of the best Pho's I have had in London.

22Q6Erh3c-rQcNwzEpAf6Q.text: The place was tiny. The staff was excellent. I tried the Spicy Green SOup Noodles. It was good. If I compare to the ramen you get in Wagamama, I think Wagamama would be slightly better. My husband had Ca Ri. It was a very small dish. Only someone with a really small appetite can have this. The quantity could have been much better.

KnFUo6XteVNGr5x-c-cOhw.text: The Bun Rieu is very very good. Almost as good as my mom's so everytime I feel like missing my mom's food, this is a good back up since aint no food as good as your mom's. The "bun rieu" at Pho's is very close to it though :-)

K7tahB3GjgHQAe2DVta1fQ.text: I really like the atmosphere. This is a really fun and lively place to go for dinner and drinks in Soho. Everything is relatively affordable, the ambiance is nice, and the service is very friendly. Unfortunately the food itself isn't great. We got a vegetarian spicy dish to take away, and the broth was very, very salty, and not spicy at all. The noodles tasted like instant noodles which was disappointing. It also costs extra to get sauce packets to go. Pho isn't the place to get the best food in the world, but coupled with the ambiance, it seems like a decent place to go with friends.

YXCVCEEUWI0FwdP78M-Q-w.text: The first time I went the food was OK and because I'm new to London I decided to give this place another try. Big big mistake the second time the food was far worse, just tasted like hot water with no real Pho flavors. But the real issue is the staff that does nothing but sit around and joke like they're out at a bar while your just trying to have a meal. Never will I go back. I wish I could give 0's all around for this establishment.

mw0bXHJsolAG1G5cP9tY-A.text: We had the beef pho and the beef meatball pho.  Both were extremely mediocre. Broth didn't taste like a full pho broth should and the meat was really thick and tough. It should be extremely thin and melt in your mouth.  Sprouts and basil were limp and turning brown. Just awful actually. As for service, the staff didn't seem to be paying attention.  I had to ask twice for water and it took awhile to get our bill.

PlOdEwDtLk-tANAkf82xpw.text: I am a huge fan of vegan pho, especially pho made with good, rich veggie broth.  That said, I really liked Pho's pho chay (made with veggie broth) and felt the broth resembled ramen broth you'd expect in Tokyo rather than tasteless broth you typically find in the USA.  The tofu was also quite tasty.  However, I specifically asked the waiter to exclude mushrooms - I really hate them - but there was a plethora of them floating around in my soup. Needless to say, I picked them out immediately, but my waiter didn't notice the problem until it was time for my check.  When the check came, there was an unexplained extra charge (for who knows what); and once I realized I tipped too much (I'm from the USA and tipped 20% when it should have been 10%), the waiter didn't give me the option to change my tip amount (mind you, I realized this as soon as I typed the tip amount in and said something immediately). Overall Rating: 3.5Food = 5.0Service (overcharge) = 3.0

photos.caption: Photo of Pho - London, United Kingdom. Vegan Pho

e5DIeM6M8kElJqlTjJMoKQ.text: My fave vietnamese place in London!! A great restaurant for vegans and/or celiacs!! Recommend their veggie summer rolls with peanut sauce & Bun Vermicelli noodles with tofu mushroom & ginger soy sauce & . YUM

-lcWXVRGLTJz1SjIW3pnZg.text: I have never been too impressed by the Pho chain, but I do admit that it's a quick way to satiate any pho cravings, especially on Sundays when most other pho places are closed. I normally order the beef brisket pho, which is about average. What I normally do not like is how lukewarm they serve the dish rather than hot as they're supposed to. Also, I always feel like the broth can be thicker and more authentic, though arguably they're erring on the safe side as not to scare away any newbies to pho. Finally, I wish they used more herbs to retain the pho-specific fragrance. Service at this particular location was solid. They were prompt and kind enough amidst the busy-ness.Ambience at the Pho chains is generally semi-hipster and modern. If you're looking for a traditional Vietnamese experience, I wouldn't recommend the Pho chains, but they're good for your casual pho meals.

tIHDZMIHdiy9OUALW6Mx5w.text: I used to be a massive fan of Pho when it first opened. the bad news is that is slipping now just like the quality control.(esp in the takeaways) there used to be lots of fresh herb flavours  like mint and coriander. They seem to be skimping on these now. Can you up the price if that is the problem?the last pho I had, had been re heated and the noodles were hot (not lukewarm as they state). Several times I have had the wrong sauce given in my takeaway.service is great here as is the ambience.

QDfn2fUz-VG2jrTZ_R1HBw.text: the noodles were broken into small pieces making it hard to eat with chopsticks. i had bun bo hue and there's not much noodles nor beef but a full bowl of soup. my partner had vermicelli with veggie spring rolls and the sauce was overly salty (u can taste the fish sauce was overpowering).

EsqkFAFM6ZOxIl2B6vmaOg.text: My boyfriend and I popped into Pho in Soho after New Year's and we thoroughly enjoyed the meal. It was my first time having Vietnamese food and it was cooked to perfection and I also enjoyed a cup of Monkey King tea - very refreshing! The prawns were big and juicy and the service was great. We are thinking that next time we are up in London we will take our friends there for a treat.
